newsitem.title: USA: Fed should rethink money market account rules--ABA.
newsitem.headline: Fed should rethink money market account rules--ABA.

text.p: The American Bankers Association (ABA) said it would ask the Federal Reserve to reconsider its petition to expand money market deposit accounts for commercial entities.
On July 10, the Fed denied ABA's request to allow for-profit businesses as many as 24 money market deposit account transactions per month, up from the current maximum of six.

"There are a lot of small businesses that cannot have interest on their checking accounts," said Jim McLaughlin, ABA director of regulatory and trust affairs. The current six-transaction limit makes money market deposit accounts impractical for them, he said.
The limit turns small businesses away from their local banks and toward mutual fund money market accounts, where different regulations apply, he said.

In his response to the ABA petition, Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan said increasing the number of allowed transactions to 24 would conflict with the Glass-Steagall Act's prohibition of interest payments on demand deposits.
"We recognize that the prohibition puts depository institutions at a competitive disadvantage and fosters a wasteful use of resources to circumvent it," Greenspan said.
"Instead of taking regulatory action that would circumvent the law, we believe that a statutory change would be more appropriate," he added.
